Course Section Definition Public Notes: All BMUS ORIN Strings students must register in MUSC 360A in their upper years. The course focuses on small ensemble combinations (trios, quartets, etc.) which will be formed in September. A regular coaching time will then be assigned to each small ensemble during the indicated hours. Each ensemble should also schedule regular rehearsal time(s) during these hours.For 3rd and 4th year undergraduates (see MUSC 160A for 1st and 2nd year registration; 560A for graduate registration).OPEN TO NON-MUSIC STUDENTS: How do I register for ensembles? For most ensembles an audition is required to secure your place. During the audition you play or sing a prepared piece for the conductor. Auditions for ensembles take place at the beginning of each academic year. https://music.ubc.ca/about/student-ensembles/

This Performance-based Chamber Music course comprises coachings and Group Performance Class in Collaborative Interpretation and Performance Practices in String/Piano Sonatas, Trios, Quartets, and Quintets Repertoire. Through interactive coachings, discussions, and in-class performances, students explore the complex analytical processes, interpersonal skills, artistic practices, and group decisions essential for dynamic interpretive collaboration and powerful co-created performance.Alternating ensemble partners and repertoire are organized by the Class Coordinator. All students attend the weekly two-hour lecture, discussion and ensemble performance class (Tuesdays). As well, they attend alternating one-hour coaching sections (Mondays at 3 pm and/or Wednesdays at 1 pm) as organized by Coordinator. Ensembles will also schedule their own additional rehearsals within those time periods.Students enrolled in this course should not schedule other activities during the Monday and Wednesday coaching hours.Please note: Requests for specific collaborations with additional colleagues may be welcome in some circumstances.This course is blended with MUSC 521D.- 3rd and 4th year BMus PIAN and String Performance majors may enrol with approval of the course instructor and their instrumental teachers. For PIAN majors, completion of MUSC 167 and at least one year of 161A with 90% minimum grade is required.- GMUS Piano 4th year students may contact instructor for permission to register, subject to completion of MUSC 167 and at least one year of 161A with minimum grade of 90, and approvals of course instructor and piano instructor.

Course Section: MUSC_V 403-C_001 - Experiencing Music-An Intro to Music Psychology (C)
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Topic: Experiencing Music-An Intro to Music Psychology

This course provides an introduction to the different research areas and methods used in contemporary music psychology to investigate questions related to the origin of music, musical domains, emotion, and well-being. Current issues such as ecological validity, individual differences, and cross-cultural research methods are discussed, and applications of findings to performance, composition, music pedagogy, and music therapy are explored.

Topic: Analysis of Video Game MusicWith MUSC 533DThis course is intended to increase students’ knowledge of the music of video games, with special consideration paid to the analytical techniques in the growing field of ludomusicology, as well as video game history.At the end of the course, students should demonstrate proficiency in a variety of analytical techniques, and possess knowledge of the craft and technologies that are involved in developing music for games of all eras. Students will also be familiar with musical conventions across various genres of video games, and will be expected to play games, emulated or otherwise, on a regular basis.Open to upper-level BMUS and BA Major/Minor in Music students. Other students should contact instructor for permission to register.

Topic: Analysis of Film MusicWith MUSC 533FAnalyzing film music requires attention not only to musical structures in isolation, but their functional and expressive roles within the broader multidimensional structure of an entire film. This course engages your existing music-analytical and aural skills in the exploration of music's powerful impact on the filmic experience, while expanding your toolkit to include vocabulary and interdisciplinary methodologies specific to film music analysis.Topics include film music practices in the silent, studio, and post-studio eras; film analysis terminology; diegetic/non-diegetic music; interaction of harmonic, leitmotivic, and other compositional techniques with parameters such as visual rhythm, dialogue, and sound design; film music cognition; and techniques for writing convincing film music analyses. Students should have completed at least two years of university-level music theory and aural skills.For anyone who is not able to register but is interested, please contact instructor for permission to register.

Topic: Music Theory PedagogyWith MUSC 533UAn overview of pedagogical philosophies and techniques for teaching music theory at the university level. Students will reinforce theory concepts, develop teaching and course design skills, and gain familiarity with current textbooks, materials, and issues in music theory instruction.
COMP Majors only.
Instructors: Dorothy Chang, Jennifer Butler, Keith Hamel, T. Patrick Carrabre

Course Section Definition Public Notes:
With MUSC 500A

In this course, we will explore analytical frameworks for making sense of tonal and triadic music. Analytical frameworks include harmonic, formal, contrapuntal, hierarchical, psychological, metrical, and neo-Riemannian models. We will apply these analytical frameworks to a variety of tonal and triadic repertoires, including instrumental music, art songs, opera, 20th-century triadic music, and more. We will also work on communicating about tonal music to others in oral and written forms.

Topic: Counterpoint (Tonal)In this course, students will explore techniques of Baroque-style counterpoint through analysis and composition. Topics will include harmonizing a subject in simple counterpoint, variation techniques, and composing in forms such as canon, chorale prelude, invention, and fugue.

Interactive Music and Performing Arts Research Training (IMPART). A digital performance ensemble using accelerometers, MIDI controllers, web cams, tablets, etc. for gesture tracking of musicians and dancers, with data controlling audio and video. Each member participates in studio and public performances each semester, gives technical presentations, and assists other members. Course pre-requisite: MUSC 320 or exceptional performance abilities in music, dance, or other performance art. 

Please contact instructor for permission to register.
Music Technology Capstone Project - Section for Term 1

Topic: Music of Africa

This course introduces students to music, musicians, and musical contexts of Sub-Saharan Africa. The course is organized around various musical elements such as timbre, rhythm, form, melody, and instrumentation. We will analyze each of these topics by juxtaposing a variety of traditional and popular case studies from eastern, western, central, and southern Africa. Comparing and contrasting these indigenous styles of musicking will allow us to understand both the unifying, pan-African components and unique, localized characteristics of each cultural practice. This will promote a broad understanding of how African music (loosely defined) is conceptualized, composed, and performed. To complement the general overview our survey provides, we will deepen our understanding of the aforementioned musical elements with a unit dedicated to the musical cultures of Zambia. Coursework includes a balance of lecturing, engagement with audiovisual material, and hands-on music making. The course does not require the purchase of any textbook; all materials will be provided by the instructor or made available in the library. It is open to all students and does not require any previous training in music or familiarity with the African continent. This course is designed to both stand on its own and complement the Music of the African Diaspora course.

Although MUSC 328 is listed as a pre-requisite, students may take MUSC 428 without a pre-requisite. To get assistance with registration, please submit a request here.

Course Section: MUSC_V 433-001 - Accompanying on the Harpsichord II
Course Section Definition Public Notes: Restricted to BMUS and GMUS. Final approval of enrolment is subject to approval of instructor, Head of the Keyboard Division, and the Director.
Restricted to BMUS. All others should contact Prof. Nancy Hermiston for permission to register (nancy.hermiston@ubc.ca).
Restricted to BMUS. All others should contact Prof. Nancy Hermiston for permission to register (nancy.hermiston@ubc.ca).

Open to 3rd and 4th year BMUS students in Voice, Opera, Piano Performance with 149/249 pre-requisite or similar transfer credits. 3rd and 4th year General Studies (GMUS) students may enroll by permission of instructor.In-depth study of Art Song interpretation and performance practice. The course has two components:1) intensive coachings for duos2) a monthly performance class with all participants.Students will select their own repertoire interests in diverse languages and stylistic eras. Emphasis is on the fusion of poetry and musical content, dramatic text-recitation, collaborative partnership and rehearsal skill-building, traditional and alternative performance practice. Those with interests in art song theatre techniques may create/perform staged works.Pre-formed singer-piano teams are strongly encouraged, but not required. Maximum number of participants: 8 singers, 4-8 pianists.The course will include weekly rehearsals, plus scheduled coachings and in-class performances during the year. Public performances will be encouraged. While duo coachings are in a private studio setting, participants are invited to audit at any time.
